channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Court in China Reduces Prison Sentence for Gao Yu, Prominent Journalist
item.description: Ms. Gao, 71, who was convicted of leaking a document that laid out plans for a campaign against Western ideas, will now serve five years rather than seven.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Gao Yu in Hong Kong in 2012. The Chinese journalist is serving her third stint in prison on politically sensitive charges.

item.title: World Briefing: Honduras: Gunmen Kill 15 People in 2 Days of Attacks
item.description: Murders of bus drivers and taxi drivers are common in Honduras and are almost always linked to the collection of extortion by any of the half-dozen gangs.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: France Votes to Keep Up ISIS Air War
item.description: The French Parliament’s upper house, the Senate, voted 325 to 0 with 21 abstentions to prolong France’s airstrikes in Syria beyond early January.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: After Paris Attacks, Ties That Bind Patrons at a Cafe Also Burn
item.description: In a city where corner bistros are havens for neighbors and friends, the terrorist attacks in Paris hurt families related by blood and banter.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: In the days after the Paris attacks, the terrace outside of La Belle Équipe became a shrine, blanketed with flowers, candles, photos of the victims and handwritten messages.

item.title: Brazilian Senator and Banker Are Arrested as Petrobras Scandal Widens
item.description: A broad investigation into corruption at Petrobras, Brazil’s state-owned oil company, widened with the arrests of a sitting senator and one of the country’s top finance executives.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA

item.title: No Known Terror Threat to U.S. Before Thanksgiving, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama said there was no specific or credible intelligence of a terrorist plot and told Americans to enjoy the holiday weekend without undue fear.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
item.description: As Crimean Tatar activists and Ukrainian nationalists prevented repair crews from getting to downed electricity pylons, Kiev closed its airspace to Russian planes and Moscow cut off gas supplies to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: ALISA SOPOVA and NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: A darkened road on Tuesday in Crimea, which has been without electricity since last week.

item.title: Obama Signs Defense Bill, Despite Guantánamo Objections
item.description: The president said he still believed that provisions in the defense policy bill making it harder for him to close the prison in Cuba might be unconstitutional and not necessarily binding.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: The prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba.

item.title: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei Says U.S. Using Money and Sex to Infiltrate Iran
item.description: Iran’s top leader warned Wednesday the United States is using “money and sexual attractions” and to not fall into the “enemy’s trap.”
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. Announces Sanctions on 2 Accused of Dealings With Assad or ISIS
item.description: The moves are the latest attempt by the administration to financially squeeze the Syrian leader and to choke off the Islamic State’s cash flow.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Kirsan N. Ilyumzhinov, shown in 2011, is accused of “materially assisting” the government of Syria and top banking officials there.

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Commander Reported Killed in Drone Strike in Afghanistan
item.description: Pakistani intelligence officials said that an American drone strike in Afghanistan had killed Khan Sayed, the leader of a breakaway faction of the Pakistani Taliban.
item.dc:creator: IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Britain’s Treasury Chief Drops Plan to Cut Welfare
item.description: The move by George Osborne, chancellor of the Exchequer, was a significant tactical retreat, in the face of political opposition, in his drive to shrink the British state and balance its budget.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Tunisia Says Attack in Capital Was Suicide Bombing
item.description: Tunisian authorities, who have declared a state of emergency, also temporarily closed the border with Libya after an attack in the capital on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Officers carried the coffin of a member of the presidential guard for a memorial service on Wednesday in Tunis, the day after a suicide bombing killed 12 guards and wounded 20 others.

item.title: Pope Francis Arrives in a Kenya Fed Up With Graft
item.description: The pontiff’s schedule for the five-day trip is packed with meetings, red-carpet receptions and a Mass on Thursday for as many as one million people.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Pope Francis arrived in Nairobi, Kenya, on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. General Says Kunduz Hospital Strike Was ‘Avoidable’
item.description: Several service members have been suspended after an internal military investigation of the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders facility in Afghanistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Gen. John F. Campbell, the top American commander in Afghanistan, called the American airstrike on a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz last month a “tragic mistake."

item.title: Navigator of Downed Russian Plane Says There Was No Warning
item.description: Contradicting Turkish officials, the navigator said he and the pilot had no time to dodge the missile that slammed into their jet.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Regulating Flow of Refugees Gains Urgency in Greece and Rest of Europe
item.description: Efforts to create centers to better process migrants heading to Europe have come into the spotlight after the terrorist attacks in Paris this month.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghans outside temporary dormitories at the site where the first registration center is going to be built on the Greek island of Lesbos.

item.title: The Latest: US Condemns Tunisia Attack, Offers Its Help
item.description: The latest on an explosion that targeted a bus carrying Tunisian presidential guards in the capital, Tunis. All times local.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Islamic State’s Bahraini Backers
item.description: Bahrain’s autocratic rulers blame democratic opponents for terrorism. That’s a grotesque distortion.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SAYED AHMED ALWADAEI

item.title: Emirates Secretly Sends Colombian Mercenaries to Yemen Fight
item.description: The arrival in Yemen of 450 Latin American troops adds a volatile new element in a complex proxy war that has drawn in the United States and Iran.
item.dc:creator: EMILY B. HAGER and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: At least 32 people were killed when a suicide bomber attacked a mosque in Sana, Yemen, in September. Dozens have been killed in similar bombings over the last six months, carried out by Sunni Islamic extremists targeting mosques where Shiite Yemenis worship.
